Fields.DialogueText: Finally! Time to make our exit from the shipyards and get back to work. Helm, all engines ahead two-thirds.
Aye-aye, Kapitan. Engines to two-thirds.
*CLANK*
What the blazes was that metal clanking noise? Is something wrong with our propulsion?
Kapitan, engines coming up to ordered speed.
*CLANK*
There it is again, and it's getting worse. I'm not imagining things! You must have heard it that time.
Da, Kapitan. When we go past five knots, it does this. Soon, there will be also be a--
*BANG*
A loud bang. Hmmm, it was a bit early that time. I am assured by First Comrade Gromky that this is normal.
WHOOO-HOO! How wonderful it feels to return to the sea, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: I couldn't agree more, Gromky. We belong on the open ocean.
Is everything all right? I heard noises.
Gromky, something is wrong in the engine room!

Fields.DialogueText: Da! We sail for GLORY!
What noises? I don't hear anything out of the ordinary?
Why must you be so critical, Kapitan? I'm fine!
I sense targets approaching, Kapitan. Let's make noise with our glorious GUNS!
What are Morganas doing so close to the shipyard? This isn't good...
@BATTLE
First Comrade Gromky, reporting as ordered to the bridge, Kapitan!
I need a full damage report from that last Morgana encounter, Gromky. Did we sustain much damage?
Hardly anything to report. Some popped rivets and a scratch or two.
Is that all?
The number 3 boiler is leaking...
Hm. I suppose it could've been worse--
The port turbine gears grind a bit, too.
I see. So that's everything--
Ah, and we've lost half of our propulsion lube oil to who-knows-where...
Lost half of our lube oil? Is that true?
I suppose that isn't exactly true.
Whew!
I mean, it isn't exactly lost. I can guess where it is.
It's probably floating about in the Baltic Sea right now.
Gromky...
Oh, one last thing. Our hydrophone system? Unresponsive. Can't hear a blasted thing with it. HA! Deaf as a POST!

Fields.MenuText: That last skirmish put us in critical condition.
We won't let the Morganas hurt us like that again!
A lesser captain might say we're screwed.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a strange thing to say, Kapitan.
Huh?
What?
The Morganas hurt us badly.
Nyet, nyet, Kapitan. All of those things I just told you? They were broken before that fight.
But... that's impossible. We just left the shipyard! You should be in top condition.
Yolki-palki! Don't blame me for all of this!
*ALARM*
Can we survive another battle right now?
Have no fear, Kapitan! Derzhi khvost pistolyetom! I promise we'll come through good as new!
@BATTLE
Kapitan, what are you doing here in the engine room without an umbrella?
An umbrella? Are you kidding?
Many people use them back here. An umbrella stops the overhead leaks and drips from staining your uniform, OF COURSE!
Blin... Now you are giving me that look.
What look?
That look. They look they all give me. That... that... ''Gromky is a floating shipwreck'' look.

Fields.MenuText: Am I wrong?
You must admit, this ship does have more than a few serious problems.
No, no... I just, um, forgot to eat anything yesterday. It, um, makes my eyes go strange sometimes when I do that.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate that, Kapitan, but I know the look.
My comrades pity me for breaking down so much. They have no faith in me.
But you did live up to your word. We came through that last skirmish, and we're still afloat.
More or less.
You should just... just go back to the bridge or to your cabin now, Kapitan. I am going to help with repairs for a little while.
Hm. She seems quite dejected. That can't be good for us in the middle of a war.
@BATTLE
So! You wanted to see me, Kapitan? Here I am!
I did. Come in and close the door, please.
WHOA! Is this about those mines I launched that I wasn't supposed to?
Huh?
Heh heh. Um, never mind! Forget I said that.
So... what can the ship's First Comrade do for her Kapitan today?
I want to discuss our destroyer's seaworthiness.
We will be FINE! I assure you of this. So much worrying... You will get WRINKLES!

Fields.MenuText: You seem self-conscious about all of the equipment problems.
Are you really going to be all right?
Don't let me or the crew down.

Fields.DialogueText: They shouldn't blame me!
I will. I hope I will. Why do people DOUBT me so much?!
Never! They have nothing to fear! And they should quit blaming me for this.
They should blame my sister, Gnevny! It's her fault. Everybody says I take after her!
*CLANK*
Calm down and don't go to pieces on me. I can see this is a sore subject.
Just one more thing. Do you really just shout words all the time like that?
Of COURSE I do! My name, Gromky... it means ''loud'' after all!
I see.
*ALARM*
Morganas? AGAIN? Time for our guns to make some noise, DA?
Let's do it!
@BATTLE
Kapitan! Kapitan! KAP-I-TANNNN!
Whoa! Gromky, I'm going to choke on my coffee if you startle me with your yelling like that.
But I have wonderful news! There... do you hear THAT?
I can't hear anything if you keep shouting in my ear.
Listen to it! LISTEN!
I don't hear anything.
Exactly! Beautiful, beautiful silence.
You're right. I don't hear any clanking or banging noises from the engine room.
Prekrasnyy, is it not? Just the beautiful music of a working engine room. It's like a Verstovsky opera to the ears!
But you can't really dance to it, I suppose.

Fields.MenuText: Great job on the repairs, Gromky. I'm impressed!
You'll just go to pieces again before long.
Is it really fixed though?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! You see now? I told you not to worry about it.
Hmph! I'll prove you wrong, Kapitan!
Da! Everything is fixed! Well, most of it is... some of it... Just be happy with me, all right?
I know my reputation is bad, but... *sniffle* I have to prove that I'm capable. I won't keep breaking down!
*ALARM*
I suppose we're about to find out the hard way.
@BATTLE
Fine job getting our engine room back in working order. Impressive work, Gromky.
Really? *sob* You truly mean that, Kapitan?
I do indeed. We've been patrolling for a bit without any propulsion problems or strange noises.
Spasibo for acknowledging the hard work. Ya schastliv! Hearing that makes me quite happy!
And now we should celebrate! Give me your cup, Kapitan.
My cup?
Da! I will pour you some Mors from my flask. Have a drink with me!

Fields.MenuText: Don't celebrate just yet. We've taken it easy so far, but things will become more demanding.
PA-RTY! PAR-TY! PAR-TY!
Whoa, wait a minute. You're drinking on the job?

Fields.DialogueText: Put me to the test, Kapitan!
DA! And later perhaps we can do some dancing!
Just a nip of my foxberry alcohol. *gulp* So sweet... *gulp* ... and it really gets your blood pumping! WHOO-HOO!
Well...
Maybe we shouldn't push our luck. Be proud, but don't slack off. Something big is coming soon.
Is this true? Tell me what it is!
Just be ready to run those engines a little harder.
We will make NOISE!
*ALARM*
Gromky, don't sound the alarm for fun. That's only for combat.
Nyet, Kapitan! I didn't sound the alarm. We have Neizvestniy Flot incoming!
@BATTLE
All damage control teams have made reports, Kapitan. No casualties, but one of our main gun turrets is stuck.
I suppose it could be worse.
And the number 3 boiler is leaking again.
And we may have lost some more oil.
Oh, Kapitan, I'm falling apart again! *sob* NOOO!

Fields.MenuText: Gun crews will just have to do their best. And we'll fix the other things, too.
Pull yourself together. Literally.
I wonder what's going to go wrong next?

Fields.DialogueText: I hope we can. We MUST!
Da. You're... you're right. You're RIGHT!
Don't say that, Kapitan! I NEED you to believe in me!
We have a chance to prove ourselves, Gromky. HQ needs us to chase down a fast pack of Morganas.
They've attacked a vital supply chain, putting thousands of merchant tonnage on the bottom.
Sounds like it will take a fast ship to catch them.
The shipbuilders in Leningrad say you were built for speed, Gromky.
My sisters and I were designed to make thirty-eight knots through the water. Some of us can go even faster. But...
But what?
But we didn't all get there. Even in sea trials. Well, I did, but my sister Gnevny said that I would never be able to keep it up, let alone crack forty--
Stop right there. Remember that reputation you were talking about earlier?
Da, of course I remember. Every day I... *sob* I live with what people must think of me. I--
You're the ship's First Comrade. This is your chance to prove yourself.
I must ask you for something now, Kapitan. Something we will need to do.
Name it.
Spasibo. It might be more fun as a surprise... I'll let you know when I'm ready!
*ALARM*
Chert! Not NOW, Morganas! Grrrrrrrr! You will eat my guns, Neizvestniy Flot!
@BATTLE
KAPITAN! KAP-I-TANNNN!
No need to shout! I'm standing right here, Gromky.
I saw you! I'm just... EXCITED! With your permission, we can begin!
You still haven't explained this plan to me. What are we doing? We can't waste any time transiting.
I gave that careful thought, Kapitan. We will not fall behind. My plan is quite simple.
Instead of cruising at a careful speed to the Barents, we will conduct a series of sprints along the way.
I see. Test your stability and endurance at high speed.
And a way to improve it, I hope. It will be just a bit like sea trials all over again!
Ughhhhh...
What?
I just realized. It will be like sea trials... ALL OVER AGAIN! Chert! What was I thinking? *sob* It's hopeless!

Fields.MenuText: Derzhi khvost pistolyetom! That's your expression, right? ''Don't give up.''
I understand the anxiety. You and your sisters have always found shipyards and sea trials to be difficult.
Should I contact HQ and refuse our mission?

Fields.DialogueText: Khorosho! Those words are ''keep your tail up with a gun,'' but yes, it means not to give up. You use it correctly.
''Disastrous'' is a better word for it! I'm SCARED!
Oh! Truly? You would do that? Do you think we should, Kapitan?
We have no choice. HQ is counting on us to stop the attacks on those merchants.
Maybe two nips from my flask would settle my nerves.
Maybe we should just get started.
Ah. Of course. *glug* Just one nip.
Flank speed, First Comrade!
Aye-aye, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
No.
GACK! My engines! Sprinting like this to test my limits is such a strain!
Helm, mind your rudder! We need a straight line, not a zig-zag.
Aye aye, Kapitan. I am trying to do this as you command me, but so much shaking at this speed is--
*WHEEEZE*
Follow the order. Gromky needs us to support her. Unless that rudder breaks off, you will keep us on course.
Da, Kapitan.
Chert! What do you want that sailor to do... *cough* ... if my rudder does break off?!
Ah, that is a good question, First Comrade! Kapitan, what should we do if--
That isn't helping, sailor.
Of course. Proshu proshcheniya, Kapitan.
Stop apologizing. Keep us on course.
Da, Kapitan. I will now stop mentioning how badly the ship is rattling and shaking.
At my top speed... I cannot... keep this up... much longer! Can I slow down yet?!

Fields.MenuText: Yes. That's enough for now.
Not yet. Keep going.
Just a little more.

Fields.DialogueText: Khorosho! I am grateful, Kapitan.
I would continue, as you command, but... *WHEEZE* I cannot. I am exhausted...
Anything I have left is yours, but the truth... *COUGH* is that I have no more. I have to stop here.
Slowing the engines to one-third, Kapitan.
Ah, such RELIEF! The aches and pains... but the next sprint will be better. How long was that one? An hour?
Gromky?
Da, Kapitan?
That was less than five minutes at your top speed.
Forty knots?
No. Thirty-eight.
WAAAAAH!
Take your frustration out on these Morganas, Gromky.
@BATTLE
Take a seat over here with me, Gromky.
Spasibo, Kapitan, but I am well enough to stand.
That last sprint could have been worse, correct? And we still made progress for our mission.
Technically, yes. We are still afloat and slightly closer to our destination.
You say these things, but... you sound disappointed, Kapitan. Was it so bad?
Let me see. Damage control reported that during those five minutes at top speed, we experienced the following casualties.
Two shaft bearings blew out. One electrical generator caught fire, but the fire was extinguished.
The fire was extinguished? Why, that sounds quite like GOOD news!
It caught fire three more times, causing electrical outages and filling the ship's ventilation with smoke.
Oh. I see. What is your assessment, then, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: It could have been worse. Not much worse, though.
Maybe we should just coast and save our strength.
Ready to go again?

Fields.DialogueText: Khorosho! Good! Then I am ready to try again with your order!
Nonsense! I think I will get stronger each time, not weaker.
Da! I will give it my best attempt, like I always do.
After all, HQ is counting on us to stop those Morganas from hunting our merchant fleet. We must prevail!
I like your determination, First Comrade. And I learned something about you.
That I have an iron heart and endless determination? That the Morganas won't stand a chance against us?
I was actually going to say that you shout a lot less when you're tired.
Oh. Haha! You know what? YOU'RE RIGHT!
@BATTLE
Chert! This sprinting to push my top speed! It is still so much of a strain for me!
Keep going, Gromky. Push yourself harder.
I am... *HUFF* pushing as hard as I can, Kapitan! Stop distracting me!
Helm, all engines ahead flank speed.
Engines ahead to flank speed, da, Kapitan.
Nyet! Chert! UGHHHH! I can't go that fast! Something will break, I just KNOW IT!

Fields.MenuText: Just a little more speed, Gromky. I know you can do it.
I give orders, Gromky, not requests. Flank speed.
What should I tell HQ? That the destroyer Gromky is just too slow for this mission?

Fields.DialogueText: I am doing my best, Kapitan! I will try...
Da, Kapitan. I will obey the order... but it HURTS!
It hurts when parts of me break, Kapitan, but barbs like that hurt more! I will prove you WRONG!
Mark our speed, Helm.
Thirty-seven knots, Kapitan.
Come on, Gromky. You were built for this. You can do it.
Thirty-seven point two. Point five. Point seven.
*CLANG*
I was designed by bumbling fools who made my sister Gnevny and did not learn from the mistake!
Thirty-eight knots, Kapitan. Thirty-eight point eight.
Fools who would put square wheels on wagons! Fools who would build a raft from stone!
*CLAAAANG*
Thirty-nine point five.
They promised me FORTY KNOTS, but gave me engines that would hardly push a child's toy! They should all be SHOT!
Thirty-nine point eight. Forty. Forty point two.
I wanted to dance on the waves, graceful like a ballerina, powerful like a storm! But I am too slow! My top speed is only--
*CLANG?*
Forty-one. Forty-one point one. Forty-one point--
Did you say FORTY-ONE?!
Good work, Gromky. Ease down and cruise for a bit. Helm, all engines two-thirds.
Slowing all engines to two-thirds, Kapitan.
FORTY-ONE?! How did I do that?!
@BATTLE
We've got Morganas. See if you can't keep some of that energy around.
Gromky? Are you out here?
Da, Kapitan. I was getting myself some fresh air and enjoying the sea. I do like it here.
This is a new experience for me.
What new experience are you talking about?
I actually had to look for you this time.
Before, I always knew where you were because I could hear you shouting wherever you went on the ship.
All of that sprinting to build up my endurance exhausts me. Sometimes I get too tired to shout.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you're pushing yourself too hard.
Good! The crew finally gets some peace and quiet without you screaming all the time.
Push harder! Your engine room can handle it if you try.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah! You are challenging me to try harder... Quite clever, Kapitan. I accept this challenge!
Haha! Kapitan, I think you are saying you miss my personality.
You're right, Kapitan. How else can I prove my sisters and I are capable?
Spasibo, Kapitan. I needed some cheering up and encouragement.
Ready to sprint again? We need to hustle to the Barents to chase down the Morganas.
Da. I am ready to go.
Are you certain? I'm not convinced.
I am... READY! I'M READY!
Now I'm convinced. Let's push those engines hard and see how fast you can go this time.
*ALARM*
HA! Morganas? Khorosho, Neizvestniy Flot! I wanted some target practice, too!
@BATTLE
I've never seen clouds so dark before!
And that lightning! So powerful! Moshchnyy! Are you scared, Kapitan?
Scared of the storm?

Fields.MenuText: That storm is too dangerous for us. We have to go around.
I'm not scared of the storm, but I'm concerned about wasting time if we have to go around.
We can handle it. Steady as she goes, Gromky.

Fields.DialogueText: The navigator says the storm will not go away for quite some time. Going around will take too long! What about our mission?!
Agreed! We have no choice.
Agreed! Onward!
We must go THROUGH!
Don't you see, Kapitan? I love to sail through bad weather like this. It is like an exciting dance!
Just get all of our crew inside. I don't want anybody tossed overboard.
Then they must hurry. The first big waves are almost upon us! WHOO-HOOO!
*ALARM*
Morganas? In this weather? If we're lucky it will clear up soon.
KHOROSHO! Which will be louder, the thunder or my GUNS? I hope the storm stays nice and loud! Fire! Fire! FIRE!
@BATTLE
Kapitan! The Morganas are gone! My guns must have battered them senseless! HA!
No visual contacts.
Certainly, I drove them away, Kapitan. I hit those Neizvestniy Flot creeps with every gun I have!
Good work, Gromky.
Well, every gun I have that still works.

Fields.MenuText: Impressive shooting!
The storm probably damaged the Morganas before the fight just as much as our guns did.
What do you mean, ''every gun that still works''?

Fields.DialogueText: HA! My secret is to shoot every gun and mine. Better chances of hitting!
You still DOUBT me?! Hmph! I will prove myself to my Kapitan as well as my sisters!
A few minor problems rotating my turrets, nothing more. When we reach the other side, we will make repairs.
I should be grateful. At least the ship didn't crack in half.
Don't doubt me, Kapitan! Just like you shouldn't doubt me when I say the Neizvestniy Flot ships are gone!
*ALARM*
Enemy contact, close aboard on our port quarter!
@BATTLE
Kapitan! KAP-I-TANNN!
For once I am grateful for your shouting! I'm wondering if my hearing is starting to degrade...
Do not ever worry about me being too quiet! I am named ''LOUD'' for a reason! HAHAAA!
How are you holding up?
I am fine, I assure you! Bouncing up and down on these wild waves... such a THRILL!
*CLANK*
Pay no attention to that noise!
*BANG*
It's probably just pots and pans tumbling about in the galley!

Fields.MenuText: I'll take your word for it.
We should investigate the ship to check for damage, just in case.
That's not the galley. Don't lie to me about things like this.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo for trusting me, Kapitan... but I'll check the engine room later. Just to make sure.
I... I suppose that would be the wisest course of action, Kapitan.
I'm not lying! I'm just trying to stay positive!
Let's head back there now. Together.
In a minute! I'm really enjoying the waves right now.
Gromky.
But...
Gromky!
FINE! But once you see that everything is in order, rejoin me on the bridge so we can enjoy the ride together.
@BATTLE
Be careful where you step in the engine room, Kapitan. The water can be quite deep in some places.
We're damn near flooded back here. How much water did we take on during the storm?
Nyet, Kapitan. This water is not from the storm. It is all from my number 3 boiler.
The boiler completely ruptured?
It finally burst, da. I hoped it was just a leak, but now I see the truth of it.
You're the First Comrade. Our ship's Belle. You couldn't sense the extent of the damage?
I felt the pain, telling me that something was wrong back here, but I didn't know exactly what had happened.

Fields.MenuText: When something breaks, you sense that as pain?
I thought Belles had a more precise sense of their ship's condition.
Is it hard to be a Belle on such a broken-down ship?

Fields.DialogueText: Da. It may not be the same for my sisters, but pain is how I perceive when something is damaged.
It may be different for my sisters, perhaps. I can only tell you what it is like for me.
Chert! I am not broken! That is exactly the reputation I want to change! If you must know? Yes! It is hard and it HURTS!
We have to deal with this mess. Get the bilge pumps running and get this space cleaned up.
Da, Kapitan. I will do it. In fact, I would prefer to be alone right now.
I'll be on the bridge, then.
@BATTLE
We spend so much time worrying about the engine room. It's unusual to be summoned to the galley.
Are you hungry, Kapitan?
Oh! I see! You wanted to share a little nip of Mors with me! Let me get my flask. I think I have enough for both of us.
Put that away, please.
Not in front of the crew, da? Suit yourself, Kapitan. *gulp* Ah, why is that so GOOD?!
Look around, please. Notice the crew?
They aren't eating. In fact, they look awful.

Fields.MenuText: They're all seasick from getting tossed about.
They're exhausted from fixing broken equipment on the ship all the time.
They're demoralized from thinking they're on a suicide mission.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, what am I supposed to do about that?!
Well, I can't help it! I... I break down sometimes, all right?!
Well, they most certainly are NOT! I am going to prove myself to them!
I'm not saying this is your fault, Gromky, or that you should take blame.
You need to see that this mission is not just about you. Or me. They need us.
As the Kapitan and the First Comrade, the crew is our responsibility. We have to care for them.
I... I care. I DO! I DO CARE!
Don't forget that, Gromky. Our people and our mission are more important than a reputation.
*ALARM*
I am so... ANGRY right now! Just like Gnevny! The Neizvestniy Flot picked a bad time to arrive in my crosshairs!
@BATTLE
Gromky?
You wanted to see me?
Come in, Kapitan! I would like your opinion on something.
A chom? A chom?
Is something wrong?
Hush! You interrupt my singing! Pozhaluysta, Kapitan, just listen...
A CHOM? A chom ty pla-CHESH, ser-TSE! A chom, a chom pechal TVA VA?
Well? What do you think of THAT!

Fields.MenuText: I didn't realize you could sing. Impressive!
I didn't realize you were a fan of Alexey Verstovsky!
I didn't realize there was a worse sound than your engines breaking down!

Fields.DialogueText: Awww, don't make me blush, Kapitan... HA! I'm kidding... I KNOW I'm great at it!
Are you a fan of his work, TOO? We should sing together sometime! It's hard to sing all the parts by myself. WHEW!
And I didn't know somebody could be MORE ignorant of art than my annoying sister, GNEVNY! You have a lot to learn, Kapitan!
That's part of an aria from my favorite of Verstovsky's operas. Askold's Grave... so captivating!
OH! We should stage an opera for the whole ship, nyet? You could even be in the show, if you wanted to be.
A... fascinating idea, but we do have important things to do right now.
Ah, I know this. I'm just dreaming a bit while I rest.
Once I prove myself capable of chasing down the Neizvestniy Flot, more people will want to be in my opera!
Thanks for sharing that with me, Gromky. Good to know that you're resting up a bit and staying in good spirits.
I do not armor my emotions, Kapitan. My feelings will always find a way to express themselves.
And LOUDLY!
@BATTLE
Do you hear that sound, Kapitan?
Don't tell me another boiler just exploded. We had enough trouble welding number 3 back together.
Listen!
Or was it one of the gun turrets? We'll have no firepower if those keep breaking down.
Kapitan, pozhaluysta! Please, just listen.
Our hull has finally cracked? Is there enough time to get to the lifeboats? I will go last, of course.
KAPITAN! LISTEN! WITH ALL DUE RESPECT, BE QUIET AND LISTEN!
But... I can't hear anything!
Exactly! Isn't it wonderful?
Oh! I can't hear anything because...

Fields.MenuText: ... because all of your shouting has finally ruined my hearing. I'm deaf!
... because we finally sank, and this is the afterlife. I'm dead!
... because nothing is broken! You're fixed!

Fields.DialogueText: I will try to calm down so that you can hear better, but you are not deaf.
Take a moment. Pinch your arm if you must, but you are not dead.
Isn't it wonderful? For now, we are in good working order.
So, our equipment is working properly. Nothing is melting... or leaking... or exploding.
That's right. Aren't you proud of me?
I am. All of your efforts to fix broken gear and to improve yourself are paying off.
Surely, I must be able to chase those Neizvestniy Flot monsters and protect that merchant shipping.
We'll find out soon. We're almost to the mission area, First Comrade Gromky.
I'm so eager to prove that I really do have endurance, Kapitan. That I'm not a hopeless wreck.
Come on out, Morganas! You Neizvestniy Flot animals will not escape my SPEED or my GUNS!
*BOOM*
Oh, no! Did something just break? Are you all right?
My apologies, Kapitan. In my enthusiasm, I accidentally fired one of my guns into the air.
That might attract some attention before we're ready. Try to keep it under control.
Too late! I sense the enemy is near!
@BATTLE
You're here, Kapitan! Have some coffee while I show you my plan.
I can see that you've drawn on these charts. Is this the merchant shipping route?
Eto pravil'no. That's correct, Kapitan. And I marked reported locations of the merchant attacks.
Most of them are in the open ocean, far from the port cities.
Da. The Neizvestniy Flot wait until the merchants, full of vital supplies, are far from ports like Arkhangelsk or Murmansk.
Too far to retreat to safety before the Morganas gun them down.
Precisely, Kapitan.
And these shapes you drew on the chart here... Blue circles, grey cubes... Is that an eyeball? A foot?

Fields.MenuText: Are these depictions of the Morganas that were sighted?
Are these diagrams for our battle tactics and code names?
Are these doodles on our navigation charts?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, those? Nyet, nyet...
Not quite, Kapitan...
Doodles?! This is ART!
I was trying to imitate some of Picasso's techniques. See the expression on that face I drew near Trondheim?
I thought that was a clock. Or maybe it's a guitar.
I am still practicing! Do not be so critical! I am SELF-TAUGHT!
And I am still your captain. Do not doodle on my charts!
I was inspired, and I had no paper to draw upon, and I...
Gromky...
Of course, of course... I will erase it. Now, when you look at our position, notice that--
*ALARM*
Explain the plan to me later. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Please? Please? Pozhaluysta, Kapitan? Can I please do a vaudeville show for the crew?
You heard me. The answer was no. Not now.
But morale is important, and the crew is nervous about our mission. Entertainment might--
But I need you concentrating on the mission, not on variety acts.
I just want you to know that I do care about the crew. I have not forgotten them.

Fields.MenuText: I haven't either. Maybe we can do a show later.
If you want to help the crew, try not to break down so much. They could use a break from all of the emergency maintenance.
If you want to impress the crew, show them your strength. Not juggling and dancing.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo, Kapitan! That is all I needed to hear.
My cheeks are red, and not just from drinking my Mors, Kapitan. You know I do not break on purpose!
There is more to vaudeville than that! Besides, I am quite a good dancer!
Just be ready. I want you to make sure everything is in good working order.
I understand, Kapitan. I was just about to tour the ship and double check.
@BATTLE
Report status of main guns.
Full range of rotation on all turrets and elevation of all barrels, Kapitan.
Excellent. Report status of--
Ask me about my mine launcher next!
Sigh. All right. Report status of--
*BOOM*
Fully operational, as you just heard! I cannot wait to sling mines at their ugly hulls! I will--
Save that ammo for the mission. Report status of engines.
They purr like a litter of kittens, Kapitan. You will have all of my rated speed and more!

Fields.MenuText: Report status of your attitude.
Report status of the crew.
Report status of your drinking.

Fields.DialogueText: My what?! My head is on straight, if you MUST ASK me ridiculous questions like that!
All present and in good spirits, Kapitan.
My flask is full of Mors! *hic* And SO AM I!
We just made radar contact with two groups. A convoy of merchants carrying food and medical supplies...
... and a battle group of Morganas chasing them. Time to move in, Gromky.
They'll never expect one of Gnevny's sisters to move so fast!
@BATTLE
That's just great...
Take THAT!
And THAT!
Don't let them get away, Gromky!
They're fast targets, but they will not escape the range of my guns! They won't get away from ME!
Catch her and put her down, fast. She's trying to lure us away from the main group.
And for that, she will suffer. ORDER ME TO FLANK SPEED!

Fields.MenuText: All engines ahead, flank speed.
Are you sure you can do it?
Don't break anything.

Fields.DialogueText: Flank speed, coming up!
Da! Just give me the order, Kapitan!
Of course. I appreciate the concern, but you will find me sturdy and seaworthy, Kapitan. Give me the order!
HERE WE GO!
Put her on the bottom, Gromky!
@BATTLE
All engines, flank speed.
All engines, flank speed.
We drove off the vanguard, and the rest of their formation looks unsteady, Kapitan!
They're far from defeated. A large part of the battle group is still chasing after those merchants.
And they are moving faster than any of the others. To catch them, I will have to push EVEN HARDER!
*BOOM*
Is our ship coming apart?
Ignore that, Kapitan. It is nothing.
Our hull! It sounds like somebody is shaking a metal bucket full of rusty bolts in here, even on the bridge!
The Neizvestniy Flot is moving so fast! Chert! They are moving at... forty-three knots?!
Even HQ never said Morganas were capable of those speeds. Damn. I wouldn't believe it if I wasn't seeing it with my own eyes.
That's even faster than my best speed. I... I can't...
Don't finish that thought, First Comrade. Without us, those merchants are as good as dead.

Fields.MenuText: Do or die, Gromky!

Fields.DialogueText: I will not fail now, Kapitan.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Just do your best. Please.
If we break apart and sink trying to save them, everybody's dead.

Fields.DialogueText: My best? I'll show you what I can do, Kapitan!
Then I will make sure such things do not happen. We will make it, Kapitan!
Quite nice of Arkhangelsk to accommodate us with a berth in their port, don't you think?
I was surprised when they made room for us so quickly, but I'm glad we don't have to anchor in the harbor.
It is a sign of respect, and I am grateful for it.
You earned it. You helped restore key merchant shipping routes.
Perhaps we earned it together.
If any ship ever pushed themselves hard and proved themselves, it was you.
Stop, Kapitan! I am swelling with pride and the emotions are... I DON'T WANT TO CRY RIGHT NOW!
Also, I cannot wait to send a message to Gnevny. I hope that slow cow will be envious of my speed.
You and your sisters. Is it always so difficult with them?
With Gnevny, da, it is. Perhaps one day we will get along better.
Perhaps.
Speaking of getting along, I think we have reached a better understanding as well. Would you agree?
I would.
In fact, if I ever command another ship, with another Belle, I'd probably hate the peace and quiet.
Oh, and I would miss the endless repairs, too.
STOP! Kapitan, you are teasing me but your jokes are not as funny as you think.
But be serious. Tell me something, pozhaluysta, if you don't mind...
Ask your question, First Comrade Gromky.
Would you REALLY transfer to another ship?

Fields.MenuText: Not yet. I think we have potential as a team if we stick together.
Not yet. Something tells me we have more to learn about each other.

Fields.DialogueText: I am glad to hear that. Even I need a little encouragement from time to time.
Oh? Something tells me that, too.
Can I offer you that nip of Mors now? My flask has enough for two.
One more pack of Morganas. Time to clean up, Gromky!
My boilers have plenty of steam for another fight. Let's GOOOOO!
@BATTLE
